author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘The Great’ and ‘Graduate Together’
description: A historical comedy series streams on Hulu, while Barack Obama joins a virtual graduation ceremony for high school seniors.
content: THE GREAT Stream on Hulu. Before starting this new dramedy, it’s best to leave your historical knowledge at the door. “The Great” refers to Catherine the Great (Elle Fanning), the 18th-century empress who became one of Russia’s most notable leaders after overthrowing her husband, Emperor Peter III (Nicholas Hoult). Created by Tony McNamara, who co-wrote the equally irreverent historical film “The Favourite,” the show favors the comical and absurd over the factual. Writing in The New York Times, Eleanor Stanford said it’s “witty and self-aware, using a charismatic woman from the past as a conduit through which to explore more modern preoccupations.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By DJ Cashmere
title: How to Let Your Children Be Upset
description: A series of children’s books can help start conversations about deeply uncomfortable subjects.
content: Anastasia Higginbotham’s first book opens with an image of a child holding a glass of milk. The sky outside is partly cloudy, but still blue. A speech bubble floats in from off the page with a parent’s words: “We have something to tell you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Cascades
description: Let’s drift downstream with Eric Berlin’s new variety puzzle.
content: CASCADES — Who says there’s nothing new under the sun? I looked high and low for a precursor to this interesting grid and came up with nothing (and then I asked the constructor, Eric Berlin, who helpfully provided some notes). On first sight, I considered it a variation on “Marching Bands,” since we’re working with two sets of clues, and every letter in the grid appears in two entries. It was a very different solving experience, for me at least; more intuitive and relaxing than “Marching Bands.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Treasury Eases Terms for Small Businesses to Convert Loans to Grants
description: A fact sheet released on Friday said businesses could get forgiveness without rehiring all their employees if the layoffs occurred early on during the lockdowns.
content: The Treasury Department on Friday made it slightly easier for small-business owners to avoid having to repay government-backed loans they took out under a program designed to keep them from laying off employees and permanently closing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Grandparents to the Rescue
description: Grandkid duty can be ‘wonderful and exhausting’
content: After nearly two months of attempting to do our jobs and also educate and care for our 7- and 3-year-olds full time, the cavalry arrived last week in the form of my parents. They are helping my husband and me with kid care, and when I saw them for the first time after our respective quarantines, I cried from joy and relief. They asked my 7-year-old how distance learning was going, and she said, “It was a mess before you got here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Suspect in Arbery Shooting Offered to Help Deal With Potential Trespasser
description: Two months before Ahmaud Arbery was killed, one of the suspects told the police he could be notified if a nearby homeowner noticed any suspicious activity.
content: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — Two months before Ahmaud Arbery was fatally shot in Glynn County, Ga., a police officer there sent a text to a property owner who was worried about recurring trespassing incidents, a lawyer for the homeowner said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and Annie Flanagan
title: A Springtime of Death in New Orleans
description: The toll of the virus has been grim in New Orleans, taking away lives while also cruelly taking away rituals of loss and mourning.
content: The toll of the virus has been grim in New Orleans, taking away lives while also cruelly taking away rituals of loss and mourning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Peter Brancazio, Who Explored the Physics of Sports, Dies at 81
description: He used science to demystify the myths of rising fastballs and Michael Jordan’s seemingly long hang time. He died from complications of the novel coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eitan Levine
title: Burying My Bubby During the Pandemic
description: The coronavirus is a deep, dark life lesson in how to experience something awful while quietly leaning over to your neighbor and whispering, “Can you believe these schmucks?”
content: One Sunday afternoon a month ago, my mother put me on a conference call with a nurse who explained exactly how we were going to say goodbye to my grandmother, Bubby. She was dying of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño, Manuela Andreoni and Letícia Casado
title: Brazil, Once a Leader, Struggles to Contain Virus Amid Political Turmoil
description: The nation’s pioneering responses to past health crises, including AIDS and Zika, won global praise. But the government’s chaotic response to the virus has undercut the country’s ability to cope.
content: Thronged banks. Packed subway cars. Buses full of President Jair Bolsonaro’s fervent supporters, heading to rallies that call on Brazilians to brush aside stay-at-home orders from mayors and governors and instead follow the president’s directive to get back to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Can Sports Help Heal a Country? Some Fans Don’t Buy the Emotional Pleas
description: The sports world has a clear economic argument for coming back to play. But is the claim that it has a larger purpose out of step with the reality of the pandemic?
content: Few things would make Pedro Urbaez happier than seeing the Mets play again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Stuck at Home, Men in Japan Learn to Help. Will It Last?
description: The coronavirus pandemic is exposing like never before the severe disparities in how Japanese couples divide household work.
content: TOKYO — Susumu Kataoka was just looking for a diversion from long days sheltering at home with his family during the coronavirus outbreak. He grabbed his drone and took it for a spin around their Tokyo house, snapping some pictures and posting them on Facebook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: 100 Babies Stranded in Ukraine After Surrogate Births
description: Travel bans have prevented the babies’ parents from entering the country. One official says as many as 1,000 babies will be born before restrictions are lifted.
content: MOSCOW — The babies lie in cribs, sleeping, crying or smiling at nurses, swaddled in clean linens and apparently well cared for, but separated from their parents as an unintended consequence of coronavirus travel bans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Phyllis George, Trailblazing Sportscaster, Is Dead at 70
description: Four years after being crowned Miss America, she became a celebrity, and drew criticism, as a co-host of the CBS show “The NFL Today.”
content: Phyllis George, who achieved one level of fame as Miss America 1971 and another four years later when CBS hired her as a member of the otherwise all-male cast of “The NFL Today,” died on Thursday in Lexington, Ky. She was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Michael Jordan: N.B.A. Champ, Marketing Legend and … Toxic Worker?
description: Experts say a difficult superstar is rarely worth the cost to workplace morale. Does the Bulls icon prove them wrong?
content: He showed little mercy when berating co-workers. He seized on their setbacks and scoffed at their maladies. He punched at least two in the head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael LaForgia and Walt Bogdanich
title: 5 Takeaways on U.S. Involvement in the World’s Worst Humanitarian Crisis
description: Thousands of civilians have died in Yemen, and American-made bombs sold to the Saudis have played a key role as the White House has sought to boost the arms industry.
content: Long before the coronavirus caused human suffering and economic chaos on a global scale, the world’s worst humanitarian crisis was unfolding in Yemen, the Arab world’s poorest country and one that has been mired in civil war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Barber Defied Rules and Cut Hair From Home. Now He Has the Virus.
description: The barber in Kingston, N.Y., is under investigation for giving haircuts during the shutdown. He lashed out at Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, saying, “Is he going to feed my family?”
content: The complaint came in last month from a resident of Kingston, a city in New York’s Hudson Valley: A local barbershop was still performing haircuts, in violation of New York’s emergency shutdown orders to thwart the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Donald Trump Jr. Smears Biden With Baseless Instagram Post
description: Signaling the increasingly dark tactics of the Trump campaign, the president’s oldest son falsely accused Mr. Biden of preying on children.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s eldest son on Saturday posted a social media message suggesting Joseph R. Biden Jr. was a pedophile, an incendiary and baseless charge that illustrates the tactics the president is turning to as he attempts to erase Mr. Biden’s early advantage in key state polls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Iran Sentences French-Iranian Academic to 6 Years in Prison
description: Fariba Adelkhah has been detained north of Tehran since 2019.
content: PARIS — A French-Iranian academic who has been detained in Iran for almost a year was sentenced on Saturday to six years in prison on national security charges, according to her lawyer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Amy Harmon and Mitch Smith
title: Coronavirus Cases Slow in U.S., but the Big Picture Remains Tenuous
description: Reports of new cases have declined nationally, and deaths have slowed. But reopening plans leave unanswered questions.
content: CHICAGO — The number of new coronavirus cases confirmed in the United States has steadily declined in recent days. In New York, the figure has dropped over the past month. The numbers have also plunged in hard-hit Massachusetts and Rhode Island, and some states, including Vermont, Hawaii and Alaska, are reporting few new cases at all.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. Lacks Leadership on Virus, Obama Tells Graduates
description: Investigators have uncovered a fraud ring that may have siphoned millions of dollars in unemployment payments. With more than two-thirds of states significantly relaxing restrictions, an uptick in cases is predicted.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: In Financial Trouble? Track Everything Companies Tell You
description: Call centers are short staffed, and employees are scattered. Mistakes are inevitable. Document any changes and offers of relief, just to be safe.
content: Every financial services company has a coronavirus relief page on its website right now, filled with reassuring language about the assistance on offer. Federal laws and regulations are supposed to make it easier to get help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wudan Yan
title: Remote and Ready to Fight Coronavirus’s Next Wave
description: An island community in Washington State has developed a testing and tracing strategy it hopes will be a model for rural and tribal communities.
content: In mid-March, Dr. Jim Bristow’s wife came down with gastrointestinal issues. Then, she couldn’t stop coughing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Hefty Barriers to Entry
description: Tracy Gray and Jeff Chen make excellent bouncers for their Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — We have a really fun, skillful construction today, by Tracy Gray and Jeff Chen, a couple of veteran puzzlemakers who have worked together before, one of whom has his hands on buckets of data and presumably compiles interesting words the way Dr. Frankenstein hoarded body parts. Its seven debuts are mainly on the edges but there are loads of clever bits and pieces everywhere, a few congenial misdirects, and maybe a sticking point or two for the casual Saturday solver. Mainly, I was pleasantly diverted by various cultural references and nostalgia, like this bunch, a very early version of the “entertaining from quarantine” family.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Brazil’s Health Minister Exits Amid Government’s Chaotic Response to Pandemic
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 16, 2020.
content: “My investment advice would be not to run into a burning building.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen A. Miller
title: Running Down a Dream
description: A writer spent a summer living and training with a team of professional runners.
content: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Crispiest Oven-Fried Potatoes
description: Patatas bravas, leek risotto, and more recipes.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include oven-fried patatas bravas with two sauces (above); chicken yassa; and leek risotto with sugar snap peas and pancetta. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Hughes
title: When the World Unravels, Braid Your Own Hair
description: I’ve worn my hair in the same exact style for six years. Learning to style it myself has brought some comfort of normalcy.
content: I’ve worn my hair in the same exact style for six years. Learning to style it myself has brought some comfort of normalcy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Roberts
title: Travels with John Conway, in 258 Septillion Dimensions
description: The Princeton mathemagician, who died in April, left an engaging legacy of numerical gamesmanship.
content: When John Horton Conway, the Princeton “mathemagician” who died in April at age 82, first found fame in the late 1960s and early ’70s, he joined the academic equivalent of the jet set. Then at the University of Cambridge, he would fly to Montreal or New York, deliver a lecture on his Conway group — an entity in the realm of mathematical symmetry that inhabits 24 dimensions — and return home all within the space of a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Kozinn
title: Astrid Kirchherr, Who Helped Create the Beatles’ Image, Dies at 81
description: The stark black-and-white photographs she took of the group in Hamburg, Germany, before the musicians were famous captured both their toughness and their sensitivity.
content: Astrid Kirchherr, the German photographer whose portraits of the Beatles when the musicians were a scruffy British bar band playing in Hamburg’s red-light district captured not only their toughness but also the sensitivity beneath their leather-clad exteriors, died on Tuesday in Hamburg, Germany. She was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Lynn Shelton Movie Moments
description: A look back at the writer and director’s films, and where to watch them.
content: The writer and director Lynn Shelton, who in the last decade emerged as a strong voice in contemporary American independent film, has died at the age of 54. Her films often captured regular people facing irregular or extraordinary, scenarios that forced them to view their lives differently. Here is a look at highlights from her filmography, including review excerpts and information on where you can stream the movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Exotic Lizards Creep Into Georgia. Don’t Expect Southern Hospitality.
description: State wildlife officials have warned residents to be on the lookout for the Argentine black and white tegu, an invasive lizard species that is threatening native creatures.
content: Add it to the list of terrors of the natural world — including murder hornets and feral hogs — that have been disrupting life these days: The Argentine black and white tegu, an invasive lizard species from South America, has taken root in Georgia, where it poses a threat to native wildlife, according to state officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlise Simons and Norimitsu Onishi
title: Rwandan Genocide Suspect Arrested After 23 Years on the Run
description: Félicien Kabuga, 84, had been on the run for 23 years, since he was indicted by the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda on multiple charges of genocide.
content: PARIS — He was behind the radio station whose hate-filled invectives turned Rwandan against Rwandan, neighbor against neighbor, even spouse against spouse. He was the man, it was said, who imported the hundreds of thousands of machetes that allowed countless ordinary people to act upon that hatred in one of the last genocides of the past century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: Justin Amash Abandons Third-Party Presidential Bid
description: The Michigan conservative said the “extraordinary challenges” of campaigning in the current environment had discouraged him from challenging President Trump and Joe Biden.
content: Representative Justin Amash of Michigan announced on Saturday that he would not pursue the Libertarian Party’s nomination for president, bringing an end to his extended flirtation with a third-party candidacy that could have introduced a new element of uncertainty into the race between President Trump and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Play-Date Arrangements: Are They Safe or Irresponsible?
description: Parents are increasingly concerned that extended isolation may stunt their children’s development. But how much risk is too much?
content: Q: My 3-year-old daughter has been home with us since March, with virtually no social contact beyond her parents. I’m worried about how an extended isolation will affect her development. Another family in our Brooklyn apartment building asked if we would be open to an exclusive play-date arrangement with their child — no other families would be involved outside of ours. What measures could we take to make sure it’s safe? Is that even possible?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Give a Different Kind of Graduation Gift
description: The class of 2020, whether in high school or college, has had a senior year like no other. So give them a fitting present.
content: The class of 2020 is graduating into an off-kilter world. Ceremonies are canceled and it’s not safe to throw an in-person party. But graduates are still celebrating. And gifts are still in order, though in interviews many graduates acknowledged the country’s economic problems, and did not want to create a stress or burden on their families. For many joy and pride are enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Summer Is Coming. Don’t Count on N.Y.C.’s Beaches for Relief.
description: Nearby beaches will open in time, but for now the pandemic will deprive New Yorkers of that pleasure closer to home.
content: For New Yorkers, a refreshing dip in the ocean at Coney Island has long been a staple of summer and a vital source of relief from the heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Sameer Yasir
title: Modi’s Popularity Soars as India Weathers the Pandemic
description: Recent polls have the prime minister’s approval ratings topping 80 or 90 percent. But the economic devastation from the coronavirus has yet to be reckoned with.
content: NEW DELHI — Just before the coronavirus arrived in India, Prime Minister Narendra Modi faced serious challenges, perhaps the biggest of his tenure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch and John Eligon
title: Obama Says U.S. Lacks Leadership on Virus in Commencement Speeches
description: The virus has “torn back the curtain on the idea that the folks in charge know what they’re doing,” the former president said. “A lot of them aren’t even pretending to be in charge.”
content: Without the springtime rituals of traditional graduation ceremonies, former President Barack Obama delivered two virtual commencement addresses on Saturday, urging millions of high school and college graduates to fearlessly carve a path and “to seize the initiative” at a time when he says the nation’s leaders have fumbled the response to the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Ziegelman
title: Where’s Our Beef?
description: Meat-eating is part of the American identity, a tradition that underlies efforts to keep slaughterhouses open despite coronavirus outbreaks.
content: In the hierarchy of essential things in America, it appears, cheeseburgers rank near the top. The president’s recent declaration that meatpacking plants are “critical infrastructure” and meat is “essential” under the Defense Production Act speaks volumes about this country’s attachment to an abundant supply of beef and pork even amid a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Blecher
title: I Left My Troubled City Behind. Now I Feel Guilty.
description: My adult son, worried about my health, urged me to flee. But New York doesn’t let go easily.
content: I didn’t want to leave the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Mooney
title: The Trout Were Socially Distant, but Not the Family Memories
description: Fishing with his adult son for the first time, the author wonders if the pandemic will be remembered as the time we were distancing and yet simultaneously being drawn closer together.
content: ATTLEBORO, Mass. — I distanced myself from my son Patrick, not as a precaution against the virus — though he is an emergency room nurse and in the thick of things — but because a novice fly fisherman poses enough danger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Photographs by Paolo Pellegrin
title: I'm Usually a Conflict Photographer. Now, I'm Documenting My Family.
description: For the first time in my career I decided not to cover a major event. I'm seeing something more timeless and universal.
content: For the first time in my career I decided not to cover a major event. I'm seeing something more timeless and universal.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jim Obergefell: L.G.B.T.Q. Discrimination Is a ‘Disgrace’
description: The named plaintiff in a landmark Supreme Court case on gay marriage discusses current L.G.B.T.Q. cases before the court.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Judge Orders Los Angeles to Move Homeless People Away From Freeways
description: The order, which takes effect next Friday, will apply to about 6,500 people living under freeways and on their ramps.
content: A federal judge on Friday ordered the Los Angeles authorities to move thousands of homeless people away from freeways and their ramps because of the particularly deadly hazards in those areas, including pollutants, passing cars and potential earthquakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: In This Election, It’s the Remote Against the Exposed
description: Those facing the greatest dangers will decide the outcome.
content: In February 2016 Peggy Noonan wrote a prescient column in The Wall Street Journal, in which she made the distinction between two classes of people: the “protected” — that is, the well-off, the connected, the comfortably insulated — and the “unprotected” — everyone else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Lynn Shelton, Director of Intimate Comic Dramas, Dies at 54
description: She got a late start on her filmmaking career but won acclaim for a freewheeling style that made room for contributions from actors like Marc Maron, who survives her.
content: Lynn Shelton, the acclaimed director of “Humpday,” “Sword of Trust” and numerous other films, died on Friday at a hospital in Los Angeles. She was 54.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anupama Chopra
title: How the Pandemic Hit Bollywood
description: The Hindi film industry came together to protect its most vulnerable after the coronavirus outbreak.
content: MUMBAI, India — “Bollywood” conjures images of ubiquitous stars, but every movie produced in Mumbai is made possible by an army of men and women toiling in the shadows: the extras, the carpenters and caterers, the tailors bent over sewing machines creating glittering costumes, the men putting up movie billboards, the men sitting in the ticket window at the local theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: At the Drive-In: Thrills, Chills, Popcorn and Hand Sanitizer
description: Cabin fever and movies drew carloads of people to the drive-in theater in Warwick, N.Y., on Friday as it opened for business again.
content: WARWICK, N.Y. — In the end, it was the rain, not the virus, that drove some moviegoers to leave the drive-in theater here Friday as a storm interrupted the season’s first shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Cody Latimer of Washington Redskins Faces Assault and Weapons Charges
description: Deputies went to an apartment complex in Colorado early Saturday morning after receiving a report of gunfire inside a unit, officials said.
content: Cody Latimer, the Washington Redskins wide receiver formerly of the New York Giants, was arrested early on Saturday in Colorado on assault and weapons charges, local officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: At the Drive-In: Thrills, Chills, Popcorn and Hand Sanitizer
description: Cabin fever and movies drew carloads of people to the drive-in theater in Warwick, N.Y., on Friday as it opened for business again.
content: WARWICK, N.Y. — In the end, it was the rain, not the virus, that drove some moviegoers to leave the drive-in theater here Friday as a storm interrupted the season’s first shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anupama Chopra
title: How the Pandemic Hit Bollywood
description: The Hindi film industry came together to protect its most vulnerable after the coronavirus outbreak.
content: MUMBAI, India — “Bollywood” conjures images of ubiquitous stars, but every movie produced in Mumbai is made possible by an army of men and women toiling in the shadows: the extras, the carpenters and caterers, the tailors bent over sewing machines creating glittering costumes, the men putting up movie billboards, the men sitting in the ticket window at the local theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Cody Latimer of Washington Redskins Faces Assault and Weapons Charges
description: Deputies went to an apartment complex in Colorado early Saturday morning after receiving a report of gunfire inside a unit, officials said.
content: Cody Latimer, the Washington Redskins wide receiver formerly of the New York Giants, was arrested early on Saturday in Colorado on assault and weapons charges, local officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: In This Election, It’s the Remote Against the Exposed
description: Those facing the greatest dangers will decide the outcome.
content: In February 2016 Peggy Noonan wrote a prescient column in The Wall Street Journal, in which she made the distinction between two classes of people: the “protected” — that is, the well-off, the connected, the comfortably insulated — and the “unprotected” — everyone else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Lynn Shelton, Director of Intimate Comic Dramas, Dies at 54
description: She got a late start on her filmmaking career but won acclaim for a freewheeling style that made room for contributions from actors like Marc Maron, who survives her.
content: Lynn Shelton, the acclaimed director of “Humpday,” “Sword of Trust” and numerous other films, died on Friday at a hospital in Los Angeles. She was 54.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott
title: Stacey Abrams Wants More Than the Vice Presidency
description: She wants the Democrats to reach a different kind of swing voter — those who otherwise stay home. And she says she can help Joe Biden do it.
content: The clapping hands appeared on the screen — one, two, a flurry of emojis —  flashing under the Facebook Live feed of the former minority leader of the Georgia House of Representatives, Stacey Abrams. It was the socially distanced derivative of the applause she has often encountered in the past year or so, since her narrow loss in the race for governor of Georgia in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: How Washington Learned to Embrace the Budget Deficit
description: Many economists who once warned of mounting debt are now urging lawmakers to spend more to combat economic pain from coronavirus.
content: WASHINGTON — This month, the federal government said it would borrow a record-breaking $3 trillion from April to June to help businesses and workers get through the coronavirus-induced recession. In April alone, the United States recorded a larger budget deficit in a single month than it did for all of the 2017 fiscal year, a total of $738 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Feds Suspect Vast Fraud Network Is Targeting U.S. Unemployment Systems
description: Investigators see evidence of a sophisticated international attack they said could siphon hundreds of millions of dollars that were intended for the unemployed.
content: SEATTLE — A group of international fraudsters appears to have mounted an immense, sophisticated attack on U.S. unemployment systems, creating a network that has already siphoned millions of dollars in payments that were intended to avert an economic collapse, according to federal authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Fred Willard, Comic Actor Who Thrived in Ensembles, Dies at 86
description: Mr. Willard, who was nominated for Emmys for his roles on “Modern Family” and “Everybody Loves Raymond,” was a frequent and memorable collaborator with the director Christopher Guest.
content: Fred Willard, the Emmy Award-nominated comic actor best known for his scene-stealing roles in Christopher Guest ensemble comedies like “Best in Show” and “Waiting for Guffman,” died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nora McInerny
title: Grieving Shouldn’t Be a Privilege
description: Many of us are experiencing loss right now. We need the time and space to process it.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — My friend Moe was back at work a week after her husband, Andrew, hanged himself by the Mississippi River, just a few miles from their home in northeast Minneapolis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Kraus
title: A Few Brave Kids Battle a Toxic World
description: In Kenneth Oppel’s “Bloom,” three meek teenagers seem poised to inherit the earth. But what kind of earth will it be?
content: If flu-pandemic books make cold sufferers anxious and zombie books make agoraphobics jittery, here’s something to rattle the Zyrtec set.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Knisley
title: Carnival Performer, Newly Separated; Attachment Issues
description: In Lisa Brown’s first long-form graphic novel, “The Phantom Twin,” a formerly conjoined twin touring in a sideshow feels the pang of cut ties.
content: In the tradition of Ransom Riggs’s “Miss Peregrine’s Home for Peculiar Children” and Katherine Dunn’s “Geek Love,” Lisa Brown’s THE PHANTOM TWIN (First Second, 208 pp., $17.99; ages 12 to 16) explores the behind-the-scenes lives of performers in an old-timey circus sideshow, tapping into our fascination — and on some level identification — with these obvious “outsiders.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Altmann
title: Married but Living Far Apart
description: Some couples, driven by their careers, decide to stay put rather than move in with their spouse. Lately, some have changed their minds about that arrangement.
content: Ian Derrer and Daniel James were married in August 2019 in the garden room of a restaurant in Santa Fe, N.M., with each of their 19 guests reading aloud lyrics to the couple’s favorite Stephen Sondheim love songs. After staying in Santa Fe for a weeklong honeymoon, during which they hiked at Bandelier National Monument and enjoyed the opera “La Bohème,” the couple drove to Dallas, where Mr. Derrer, 45, lives. The next day, Mr. James, 33, left for Houston, where he lives.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 16, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 16, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about threats to the movie theater industry and innovations that might  revive it misstated the expected release date of the film “Jurassic World: Dominion.” It is the summer of 2021, not this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: David Carter, a Historian of Stonewall, Is Dead at 67
description: His research into the 1969 uprising that was a turning point in the gay rights movement helped get the site of that uprising recognized as a landmark.
content: David Carter, whose careful research into the Stonewall Inn uprising of 1969, a pivotal event in gay rights history, culminated in an authoritative book on the subject and helped win the area in Greenwich Village where the episode occurred a listing in the National Register of Historic Places, died on May 1 at his home in Manhattan. He was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang, David McCabe and Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: U.S. Is Said to Plan to File Antitrust Charges Against Google
description: The case may be joined by state attorneys general in what would be one of the biggest antitrust actions by the United States since the late 1990s.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is planning to file antitrust charges against Google as early as this summer, said two people with knowledge of the situation, in what would be one of the biggest antitrust actions by the United States since the late 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Removes State Dept. Inspector General
description: A top Democrat in Congress described the move as “an outrageous act,” and said that the inspector general, Steve Linick, had opened an investigation into Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump continued his purge of inspectors general late Friday, moving to oust Steve A. Linick, who had served in that post at the State Department since 2013, and replacing him with an ambassador with close ties to Vice President Mike Pence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Read the Full Transcript of Obama’s H.B.C.U. Commencement Speech
description: Former President Barack Obama addressed a ceremony for graduates of historically black colleges and universities. Here is what he had to say.
content: Former President Barack Obama gave the virtual commencement address at a ceremony for graduates of historically black colleges and universities on Saturday. The two-hour event, “Show Me Your Walk H.B.C.U. Edition,” celebrated more than 27,000 students from 78 schools.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Horse Racing Tracks Can Open in New York in June, Cuomo Says
description: Some horse racing, as well as some auto racing, will be allowed to go ahead next month as New York State begins reopening nonessential businesses in several regions.
content: Governor Andrew M. Cuomo said Saturday the state would allow horse racing tracks and the Watkins Glen International auto racing track to open without fans on June 1, opening the door for televised events at those venues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germany Criminalizes Burning of E.U. and Other Foreign Flags
description: The new ban, relatively rare in the world’s legal codes, was proposed as a response to the burning of an Israeli flag at a demonstration in 2017.
content: BERLIN — German lawmakers have voted into make the destruction of foreign state flags, including that of the European Union, and the denigration of national anthems punishable by a fine and up to three years in prison, in a relatively rare move by a government to protect the symbols of other nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Wide-Open Spaces
description: Byron Walden slows our roll with a tough Sunday puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — We are fast approaching Byron Walden’s 100th puzzle for The Times, and he’s prolific elsewhere (including the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament). I think today’s construction is an escalation in the unthemed Sunday crossword monster construction race, as it has only 122 entries, tied with a beast from last year by Frank Longo (fewer answers make puzzles tougher to solve and absolute bears to build, as a rule). As its title intimates, this grid also has 177 “open squares,” which are empty squares that don’t touch any black block, even diagonally, third only to a 218 Patrick Berry Sunday puzzle and the aforementioned Longo puzzle. Joel Fagliano has made a 124-answer Sunday puzzle in the last year as well; all of these have been unthemed. Perhaps one day we’ll get a collaboration between all of these constructors with 42 spans and no black squares at all, and someone will still drop a “too easy!” in the comments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: McConnell’s Rush to Protect Businesses Endangers Everyone Else
description: To reopen safely, companies need good, clear and mandatory guidelines, not immunity from liability.
content: There’s a tension at the heart of all of the plans to reopen the country in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic: The economy needs Americans to get back to work, but workplaces need employees and customers to feel that coming back won’t endanger their health or their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Kaplan
title: F.D.A. Clears Another Coronavirus Testing Kit for Use at Home
description: The agency granted emergency clearance for a testing kit that allows a consumer to take a nasal sample at home and send it to a laboratory for the diagnosis.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Saturday granted emergency clearance for a coronavirus testing kit that will enable individuals to take a nasal sample at home and send it to a laboratory for diagnostic testing, the second such approval it has made.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac, Sheera Frenkel and Cecilia Kang
title: Now More Than Ever, Facebook Is a ‘Mark Zuckerberg Production’
description: For years, he was an obsessive C.E.O. in some ways, distant in others. Then Facebook’s problems became too acute to leave to anyone else.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — On Jan. 27, at a regularly scheduled Monday morning meeting with top executives at Facebook, Mark Zuckerberg turned the agenda to the coronavirus. For weeks, he told his staff, he had been hearing from global health care experts that the virus had the makings of a pandemic, and now Facebook needed to prepare for a worst-case scenario — one in which the company’s ability to combat misinformation, scammers and conspiracy theorists would be tested as never before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael LaForgia and Walt Bogdanich
title: Why Bombs Made in America Have Been Killing Civilians in Yemen
description: President Trump sees arms deals as jobs generators for firms like Raytheon, which has made billions in sales to the Saudi coalition. The Obama administration initially backed the Saudis too, but later regretted it as thousands died.
content: Year after year, the bombs fell — on wedding tents, funeral halls, fishing boats and a school bus, killing thousands of civilians and helping turn Yemen into the world’s worst humanitarian crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Doctor to Congress and Supreme Court Toils to Sidestep Politics Amid Pandemic
description: Dr. Brian P. Monahan has found himself in the middle of politicized debates over how quickly to reopen the country and who should be testing for Covid-19.
content: WASHINGTON — When Senator John Barrasso, Republican of Wyoming, sought guidance on how to protect his family, including his 94-year-old father-in-law, when he returned home from the nation’s capital amid the coronavirus pandemic, a doctor offered him some blunt advice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Amazon Reaches Deal With French Unions in Coronavirus Safety Dispute
description: The online giant will begin reopening its six warehouses in France following a legal battle over protections for employees.
content: PARIS — ​Amazon has reached an agreement with French unions to reopen its warehouses in France after a lengthy battle over safety measures to protect workers against the coronavirus, capping the most prominent labor showdown the retailer has faced during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Saudi Arabia’s Big Dreams and Easy Living Hit a Wall
description: The coronavirus pandemic and falling oil prices have yanked the rug out from under Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s development plans and curbed government largess.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia knows about head-spinning change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Michael D. Shear
title: Trump Ousted State Dept. Watchdog at Pompeo’s Urging; Democrats Open Inquiry
description: The lawmakers said Steve Linick, the State Department’s inspector general, had opened an investigation into Secretary of State Mike Pompeo’s conduct.
content: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo urged President Trump to fire the official responsible for fighting waste and fraud in his department, a White House official said Saturday, a recommendation certain to come under scrutiny after congressional Democrats opened an investigation into what they said “may be an act of illegal retaliation.”
source.name: The New York Times
